reviews.text: Cats may not leave its audience in awe the way Les Miserables did but it does have its own charm. The best way to approach the movie is to go into the cinema knowing you will be about to watch a theatre production rather than a big blockbuster film.
reviews.author: David Griffiths

reviews.text: If the cast and crew wanted audiences to feel like cats– easily distracted and bothered by almost everything– they’ve succeeded.
reviews.author: Brittany Patrice Witherspoon

reviews.text: It is unlikely anyone will be feline good after witnessing this cat-astrophe because ultimately it was the morbid curiosity that killed the Cats…
reviews.author: Dallas King

reviews.text: I’m sure Taylor Swift’s next big hit will be a song about the jilted experience.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: If by some chance, “Skimbleshanks the Railway Cat” doesn’t make you want to poke your ears out and wish that music had never been invented, bless your sincere, furry hide.
reviews.author: Pat Padua

reviews.text: At best, it’s an ambitious misfire. At worst, it’s straight-up nightmare fuel that will haunt generations. Enter into the world of the Jellicles at your own peril.
reviews.author: Daniel Howat

reviews.text: Ugly, annoying and inconsistent
reviews.author: Brian T. Carney

reviews.text: "I think there's a film version of "Cats" that could work, but this isn't it."
reviews.author: Catherine Gonzales

reviews.text: I finally understand that one episode of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.
reviews.author: Cate Young

reviews.text: No disrespect to people who love this musical, this is the worst movie of the year... next year too.
reviews.author: Lonita Cook

reviews.text: ...unable to claw itself away from its detracting visuals.
reviews.author: Hagan Osborne

reviews.text: I want to tell you I at least had fun... but this movie is also so horrible it doesn't even earn the status to make fun of magicians.
reviews.author: Lindsay Traves

reviews.text: Watching the film version of Cats is truly mystifying, in neither a completely bad nor completely good way. Fans of the theater production may enjoy seeing their favorite songs or characters again, but there's little to recommend for anyone else.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: With actors who appear to have been put through the full-body Snapchat cat filter, a Ziegfeld Follies-style chorus line of dancing cockroaches and felines with human hands and feet, you'll wonder if the theatre popcorn is laced with catnip.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: I, for one, felt lost, grappling down a sketchy back alley for rhyme, reason and, once the credits rolled, the nearest exit.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: [The] stars must be coughing up hairballs after joining the film's giant litter of singing and dancing felines, whose weird digital fur and creepy features make them all look as though they've been dragged in from the Island of Dr Moreau.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: May be too indigestible even for a hate-watch.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: Enraging, unfathomable, and laughable, Cats is a masochistic experience, that this reviewer rather hesitantly recommends - if only for the gamut of emotions it will take you through, leaving you scratched all over.
reviews.author: Harris Dang

reviews.text: Cats is disjointed, unintentionally comical, and a little creepy - and folks, I love musicals.
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: Cats may very well be the most unique film of the year, certainly released by a major studio, and you'll love it and hate it but you sure won't forget it.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: Dragging on for almost two hours of poor singing and predominantly forgettable choreography, Cats is Hooper's way of maliciously toying with us like a half-dead mouse wishing for sweet release.
reviews.author: Stephen A. Russell

reviews.text: Add in the tonal shifts and performances that never feel like they're in the same movie, and out comes a cat scratch fever dream that can only be enjoyed ironically.
reviews.author: Matt Cipolla

reviews.text: Every ounce of goodwill built by the feline community in this economy of viral cat videos and memes has been squandered by a single movie.
reviews.author: Prahlad Srihari

reviews.text: This is like doing too much catnip and falling asleep to the soundtrack, just surreal. Your MEMORY of the story may change, but the curiosity to see it won't kill you. Hy-ooh!
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: There's no use crying over spilled milk. ... It's a boo hiss - unless you're insanely curious to witness something so awesomely bad. Just remember: curiosity killed the cat.
reviews.author: Jason Fraley

reviews.text: I've never used drugs but I suppose the feeling is close to what I experienced watching Cats. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Gallegos

reviews.text: It is an oddity all to itself, a spectacular disaster in every sense of the term. It's a drug-induced hallucination brought to life.
reviews.author: Allen Almachar

reviews.text: Just don't think of it as a film, and you'll be fine.
reviews.author: CJ Sheu

reviews.text: What did I just watch?
reviews.author: Doug Walker

reviews.text: Cats might be an example that just because something can be done doesn't mean it should be, and that some titles are better left for the stage.
reviews.author: Nikki Francisco

reviews.text: I'm not sure what the hell I just saw, but I definitely know I wasn't high enough for whatever it was.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: I would not relish the opportunity to see it again and will happily forget it, as soon as possible.
reviews.author: Caitlin Kennedy

reviews.text: I was always a dog person anyways.
reviews.author: Vera Wylde

reviews.text: The film is flat, without any of the camp, kitsch high energy that characterised the stage show, but its wrongness is never less than mesmerising.
reviews.author: Deborah Ross

reviews.text: What worked for Andrew Lloyd Webber and the Broadway cast/crew only transcribes to the screen half the time.
reviews.author: Wendy Shreve

reviews.text: A film that seeks to inspire our loathing for nearly every frame it sits on the screen, and that is before we even attempt to decipher the mediocrity that is the music or the nonexistence of the story.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: Hooper's ill-advised creative decision of making them as human as possible, except with the face and body of a cat sure gives me the creeps.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: Here we get a deadening and earthbound Rebel Wilson as Jennyanydots, a comic turn that, nonetheless, calls for movement. And Mr. Mistoffelees' magic becomes a matter of special effects, not sublime dance moves.
reviews.author: Eleanor Ringel Cater

reviews.text: An invigorating failure. One-of-a-kind filmmaking.
reviews.author: Evan Dossey

reviews.text: A money pit of terrible ideas executed terribly, Cats stands as a monument to ineptitude and unimaginativeness. Everything looks disturbingly wrong from the very first frame right through to the very last.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: You'd think you couldn't make a scene like 'WereCat Taylor Swift literally drugs a roomful of other cat-persons into a horny psychedlic frenzy for her suggestive burlesque number' inert and bland... but they found a way.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: A deranged freak-fantasia worth falling into for a couple of hours, if just to say you did. That is to say, it's Cats.
reviews.author: Isaac Feldberg

reviews.text: Purr-fectly dreadful.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: What sort of fur is it? It's like cannibalism.
reviews.author: Avaryl Halley

reviews.text: The movie was garbage.
reviews.author: Andrew Galdi

reviews.text: The worst movie I have seen in my lifetime...the movie is oddly over-sexualized and the music is not moving...what was going on?
reviews.author: Shawn Edwards

reviews.text: You can't believe what you're looking at because it's so hideous to behold.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Clearly, Hooper's film, while riddled with glaringly awful mistakes, is not bad at all.
reviews.author: Oggs Cruz

reviews.text: A feast for the senses!
reviews.author: Jaime Davis

reviews.text: Seeing Jennifer Hudson's snot continue to glisten over her lips, refusing to be wiped away, made me Google, "Can you lose an Oscar?"
reviews.author: Jordan Calhoun

reviews.text: The best thing here is that it's at least under two hours. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: The film is a triple-decker weirdburger from the twitching ears to the too-long tails that make the ensemble look like lemurs.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: There's a digital veneer of horror and farce and glazed looks, and it just doesn't work, it's not sensibly thought about.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: I struggled throughout the movie to not fall asleep. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: William Venegas

reviews.text: The star power likely won't save this non-Jellicle movie of 2019. A theatrical powerhouse, CATS didn't translate well from theater to film. The songs were great, but the actors struggled to find an objective with the absence of any storyline.
reviews.author: Vincent Schilling

reviews.text: Cats' main sin... is that it is boring. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: The CGI turns the kitsch of the original work into something more disturbing than entertaining. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: María Fernanda Mugica

reviews.text: In The End: Cats is a CG horror of weird cat mutants dancing and singing nonsense in weird people-sized settings with no people. Run away.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: As the minutes tick by clocking in almost two hours, Cats comes off as a mix of bizarre and boring.
reviews.author: Sreeparna Sengupta

reviews.text: Might as well have not existed, as far as I'm concerned. Does this movie have any redeeming qualities?
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: Just bad, a new rating...Tom Hooper was up for thirty-six hours straight, which means he was just losing his mind...too far gone...
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: After an hour of Cats I began to suspect the popcorn they fed us had been laced with a psychotropic drug.
reviews.author: John McDonald

reviews.text: It's Judi Dench as Old Deuteronomy and Ian McKellen as Gus the Theatre Cat who save the musical from mediocrity. Their voices aren't particularly strong, but their acting is the cat's pajamas.
reviews.author: Cameron Meier

reviews.text: What should be a delightfully quirky romp quickly turns into a nightmarish fever dream instead. The CGI descends to the depths of the uncanny valley.
reviews.author: Sameen Amer

reviews.text: This is inconsistent stuff, surely, but "Cats" is also rewarding enough in bursts of passion that make it a genuinely intriguing experience.
reviews.author: Andrew Kendall

reviews.text: A feverish and cacophonic dream that intermittently licks your senses but it always scratches your brain. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: While the performances are brilliant and the songs are great, the story isn't as strong as it could be.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: It's cartoonish, a little surreal and, at least to this grumpy (cat) critic, altogether irresistible.
reviews.author: Rubén Rosario

reviews.text: Brilliant music, well-choreographed songs and good production value couldn't save this one from sinking.
reviews.author: Analita Seth

reviews.text: The movie "Cats" is-forgive the critical jargon-pretty good.
reviews.author: Richard Brody

reviews.text: However amazing the trickery may be... the characters fall awkwardly into the crack between animal and human, and the plot, which requires them to sing and dance in competition with one another, is scarcely more convincing.
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: In it, Ian McKellan (winner of 6 Laurence Olivier Awards, a Tony, a Golden Globe, a SAG Award, 4 Drama Desks, and 2 Critics' Choice Awards, a two-time Oscar and four-time BAFTA nominee) says the words 'meow, meow', while licking the back of his hand.
reviews.author: Rohan Naahar

reviews.text: Sometimes a movie struts its awfulness with such glee that it almost becomes an enjoyably sadistic pleasure rather than a chore to watch.
reviews.author: Louisa Moore

reviews.text: Cats absolutely does commit to every choice it made. I would like to respect it for that, but the choices were bad.
reviews.author: Eve Tushnet

reviews.text: There is fun to be had at this adaptation of the blockbuster stage production, and it's the holidays, so you might as well have it.
reviews.author: Lisa Jensen

reviews.text: Cats is not for everyone, but it is definitely for me.
reviews.author: Chase Burns

reviews.text: One of the biggest misfires I've ever seen on the big screen. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: The filmmakers were so preoccupied with whether or not they could do a heavily CG version of Cats, they didn't stop to think if they should.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: The longer I watched this two hour cinematic car crash, I could begin to see inspired shards of a what could have been a masterpiece in the twisted carnage flickering in that darkened theater.
reviews.author: Dan Tabor

reviews.text: The most shocking thing about Cats is that it's somehow worse than you imagined it could ever be.
reviews.author: Rachel West

reviews.text: Inscrutable and ignominious - a veritable cat-astrophe!
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: While it was a challenging musical to adapt to screen, Cats was a mess and I regret not drinking a lot before seeing it.
reviews.author: Megan Williams

reviews.text: The problem with the film is that it shouldn't exist in the form that it does, and no single thing would have solved that.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: You thought we stopped at cat-human hybrids? Oh no...nightmares. A nightmare that does not end for two hours.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: There will be people, fans of the musical, that will both give them what they want and something new...so much of it plays, even in concept, to just loving cats and giving them personalities. If you have that sort of affection, you probably go with it.
reviews.author: Martin Thomas

reviews.text: It is a movie that never stops throwing 50 shades of WTF at you, but never once starts making sense.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: For me, Cats was magical... It kept in songs I was sure would be cut and it was so boldly and confidently Cats that I had to respect it and I truly enjoyed each moment.
reviews.author: Jessica Mason

reviews.text: Whether you think the imagery is beautiful or nightmarish, this is a film that demands to be looked at.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: It's a brave attempt to do something new, but the result is a movie that will draw an audience simply because it's such a colossal misfire. And whether you think it's good or bad, the film is packed with unforgettable moments.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: I can say with all sincerity that upon finally meeting Cats face to face, somewhere past the introduction of the wayfaring Grizabella and the sage Old Deuteronomy, I was dazzled.
reviews.author: Michael Arbeiter

reviews.text: We will not see the likes of Cats again. Which, in a way is a shame. This is one of the worst films I've ever seen. I also hope that everyone goes to see it and that it wins Best Picture at the Oscars in 2020. Can't recommend it highly enough.
reviews.author: Fiona Underhill

reviews.text: A surreal, disturbingly sexual, and profoundly disquieting experience. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Pussy galore, and quite the bore.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Hooper's surrealistic song-and-dance spectacle, steeped in joyous musical theatre lore and rich with the emotions of acceptance and forgiveness, is exactly what we need right now.
reviews.author: Simon Foster

reviews.text: You need to suspend disbelief. Don't fight the visuals. Movies can be fantasies, and "Cats" is one heck of a fantasy. The film is better than the stage production because it's more expansive. The action is opened up. The singing is gorgeous.
reviews.author: Michael Calleri

reviews.text: A truly terrible 'Memory' that will haunt me for a thousand lifetimes.
reviews.author: Richard Bardon

reviews.text: The movie is outlandish and sexual and confusing. But that doesn't make it a bad movie. In fact, I'm going to call it a good movie.
reviews.author: David Oliver

reviews.text: It's just baffling and yet it must be seen... It's bad, but you've got to experience it.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: It's not the film-making that is wrong with Cats, it's the fact that the film even exists.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: Whether or not you ultimately warm to the out-there story about a tribe of cats who hold an annual sing-off to decide which of them will ascend to a new life in the heavens, Hooper's CGI-live action hybrid is oddly bewitching.
reviews.author: Vicky Roach

reviews.text: Me as a teenager seeing Cats on Broadway: "This is terrible. Easily one of the dumbest, weirdest, most incoherent and pointless things I've ever seen." Tom Hooper's Cats movie: "Hold my beer."
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The feline spectacle has a dadaist feel, and in its first hour, it is truly soporific. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alberto Luchini

reviews.text: It's already been mentioned that the visual effects are not what will annoy you the most; however, that does not mean they are good. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Abigail Camarillo

reviews.text: A visual event of catastrophic proportions. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sergio López Aguirre

reviews.text: [Cats] is one of those absurd and crazy movies that everyone wants to see because it guarantees a good time. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Elsa Fernández-Santos

reviews.text: The movie's slow pacing might put off most people.
reviews.author: S. Indra Sathiabalan

reviews.text: And that is Cats' main failing - the hubris that assumes what works on stage works just as well on screen.
reviews.author: Jonathan Roberts

reviews.text: The movie IS bad - but not enough to be interesting (Hooper is incompetent even in his incompetence). The result is a stupid and aesthetically heinous bore. [Full review in Portuguese]
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Anthropomorphic cats with uncanny valley, bad cat puns, and so many crotch shots-oh so many crotch shots...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: Having a literal cat claw at my eyes for an hour and forty-nine minutes would have been less painful.
reviews.author: Kent Garrison

reviews.text: Furries rejoice! Tom Hooper and Universal have spent around ninety-five million dollars on your dream movie ... For the rest of us, the film is a clear misfire, misconceived and badly executed.
reviews.author: CJ Johnson

reviews.text: While it's far from being perfect, or even purr-fect, it certainly doesn't warrant the abuse that has been heaped upon it. At the very least, it deserves a chance.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: For all of the star power on display, this is an indoor Cats: spayed, defanged and thoroughly domesticated.
reviews.author: Jay Horton

reviews.text: It instils a Lovecraftian madness in the viewer, the silver screen becomes a billowing veil of darkness.
reviews.author: Cian Geoghegan

reviews.text: Tom Hooper's freakily phantasmagoric visualisation of an already strange West End smash is a high-wire act... And yet it never falls, sustaining a subtly hallucinatory, wholly theatrical reality.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: You might still want to know if it's a good movie, but that is the wrong question. Cats is sui generis.
reviews.author: Rumaan Alam

reviews.text: After two hours of the finished product, the animal-human hybrids redefine uncanny valley. It is hard to know where to look, or even create the desire to stare at Tom Hooper's godforsaken creation.
reviews.author: Carmen Paddock

reviews.text: Cats' biggest problem is its director. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Eulàlia Iglesias

reviews.text: While it is mostly jaw-dropping, there are still a few good moments, to be relished and savoured like a stinky five-day-old fish rescued by James Corden from a bin.
reviews.author: Sarah Cartland

reviews.text: If you loved the play you will most probably love the movie. I abhorred the play so the movie didn't stand much of a chance. Still it was better than I expected (which wasn't much).
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: There are not enough redeeming qualities in this incoherent, disturbing and lifeless musical mess. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rene Sanchez

reviews.text: How could anyone have hoped the film version would be a masterpiece when the stage musical it is based on is pretty dreadful?
reviews.author: Jo Berry

reviews.text: If you're a fan of the musical, or a member of the cast, then by all means go see "CATS." If you're not a fan of musical theatre, go stand in line and see "Star Wars" again.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: Cats has unfairly received withering criticism. If you liked the Broadway musical, you will like the film.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: The Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, based on T.S. Elliot's wonderfully creative "Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats," played on Broadway for 18 years despite not being very good. But it was fun in a way this big screen CATastrophe isn't.
reviews.author: Asher Luberto

reviews.text: As the trailer suggested, the enduring stage musical is a bad fit for the big screen.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Cats is a tortured fever dream of a film...the unholy offspring of a coked-up studio executive notes session and a dark ritual intended to summon forth the Elder Gods. We are all cursed. We are all damned. We are all Cats.
reviews.author: Allen Adams

reviews.text: The definitive film adaptation of one of Broadway's most successful musicals.
reviews.author: Alan Ng

reviews.text: A borderline unwatchable mishmash of poorly conceived musical numbers and incoherent storytelling.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: Even Stewart's colorful sets, Weber's delightfully esoteric songs, and Blankenbuehler's beaming choreography aren't enough to sustain the interest of most who will go in knowing nothing.
reviews.author: Luke Hicks

reviews.text: More is less, but sure - let's go all in... looking like a remake of The Wizard of Oz as a 1980s interpretive-dance video on MTV where all the characters have been replaced by human-feline hybrids...
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: The movie is literally Caligula meets The Aristocats, something all cult film fans must see. It's not great by any means, but the bad movie fan in me loves it
reviews.author: EJ Moreno

reviews.text: Perhaps the least chill Broadway musical of all time
reviews.author: Jenni Miller

reviews.text: The star-struck Cats is a rare attainment and could well be the last of the film industry's industrial-scale caprices, a follicular folly down to molecular level.
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: Despite some clever additions to the stage musical, Tom Hooper's adaptation produces many bad, and bizarre, memories.
reviews.author: Glenn Sumi

reviews.text: All of it seems quite alienating most of the time. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: It's like watching someone watching the movie, which is itself like watching cats dry.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: I don't want to hear Memory again for a very long time. Miaow!
reviews.author: Matthew Bond

reviews.text: An incoherent pastiche that combines theater, film, and digital technology with virtually no skill. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Paula Arantzazu Ruiz

reviews.text: Every now and then a film comes along that requires a level of strength, courage and, indeed, patience, the likes of which I am simply unequipped for.
reviews.author: Chris Wasser

reviews.text: You feel like sitting Hooper down in front of a film musical - White Christmas, Singin' in the Rain, anything - and saying: "You see these bits in between the songs? That's called a 'movie'."
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: That this material seems incapable of articulating any reason for its existence may be its greatest fealty to the cruel and unknowable animal kingdom. Cats is stubbornly meaningless.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: There's something uniquely fun about seeing the likes of Ian McKellen and Jennifer Hudson fully committing to their down-on-their-paws characters, a spirited sense of shared strangeness.
reviews.author: Mary Elizabeth Williams

reviews.text: [Cats] manages to unearth an extra layer of awfulness and heap it upon the source material for a nightmarish affair that could do for felines what Jaws did for sharks.
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: If you are big fan of the musical, than Cats is a must-see for you. For the rest of us, it has some charming performances and good star power, but less visual effects dazzle than might be expected.
reviews.author: Cate Marquis

reviews.text: So, in conclusion, I say to Old Deut, you have not convinced me. I remain resistant to conversion. I am now and forever, a dog person. Hiss if you will, but to you I say, arf or maybe arf and one half.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Believe me when I say it more than lives up to the hype.
reviews.author: Emma Specter

reviews.text: The film is an unholy melange of humans making cat moves - like head-nuzzling - and "cats" doing human things.
reviews.author: Al Hoff

reviews.text: The worst thing about Cats - and I was forced to see two cat burglars sensually drape a string of pearls around the scruff of Hayward in the obvious foray to a cat threesome - is that it was made in the first place.
reviews.author: Chandler Levack

reviews.text: This is a film that reeks of misjudgment.
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: What is this movie?
reviews.author: Andre Meadows

reviews.text: Tom Hooper's Cats has potential but isn't quite there with the CGI and visuals to make this into a good movie just yet.
reviews.author: Lauren Veneziani

reviews.text: A film of unrelenting upbeat energy, so horrible that it's only really possible to react to it with a kind of delirious manic good cheer.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: It lacks the depth of character and comprehensive world building needed to transcend its theatrical origins and become a complete movie with a fully realised narrative.
reviews.author: Damien Straker

reviews.text: A complete and utter artistic failure, if also fascinating enough in its awfulness to likely endure as a perversely-admired cult classic. It could've been worse - it could've been boring.
reviews.author: Shaun Munro

reviews.text: You'll never forget it - though you will try.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: Cats might be a mess, but it's a one-of-a-kind incredibly memorable mess (for better and for worse), and for all I know that's entirely by design.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: Seemingly scooped out of the litter box, it's best viewed under the influence of catnip or some other hallucinogenic substance.
reviews.author: Neil Morris

reviews.text: Where do you even start with Cats? Tom Hooper's big screen version of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical is unlike anything you've ever seen before, but not in a good way.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: Cats is one of the worst movie musicals of all time, a stagnant mess from start to finish.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: This is middlebrow film-making at its most hubristic; too inelegant to coast on spectacle alone, it's not subversive enough to be considered truly camp either.
reviews.author: Simran Hans

reviews.text: It's one of those rare cinematic events that feels like a collective hallucination - improbable and entirely indescribable.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: "Cats" is a Purr-fectly fun and truly entertaining film.
reviews.author: Leah Sydney

reviews.text: Cats is a punishment.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: What, you may ask, the f***?
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: I hated this movie with every fiber of my being.
reviews.author: Scott Wampler

reviews.text: Once Rebel Wilson and James Corden's bits are out of the way it's easy to settle in and enjoy the beautiful music and choreography.
reviews.author: Millicent Thomas

reviews.text: I spent most of Cats with my hands over my mouth, going "What is happening?"... I had a ton of fun with this.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: Hooper and company have - yes, I'm going to say it - spit up a huge hairball with their Cats. Forgoing substance in favor of the cheap buzz of spectacle rarely ever works in film, and in this case, the spectacle doesn't even work.
reviews.author: Frank Wilkins

reviews.text: Visually repulsive and not far behind on a sonic level.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: Cats is a musical extravaganza that is toe-tapping, energetic and utterly endearing.
reviews.author: Ben Rolph

reviews.text: ... a bewildering and curiously flat adaptation that will leave many moviegoers scratching their heads - or anything else their paws can reach.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: Chiefly, a terrible, terrible movie.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: A cat introduces themselves, sings about their one thing, Macavity shows up to be evil, rise and repeat for nearly two hours. That...that's honestly all there is to say.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: So bad it's destined for a box of kitty litter.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: In the hands of filmmaker Tom Hooper, he's turned this surreal concept concerning the meaning of life and death into something of a freak show.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: Our best bet is to pack it into a crate lost deep within a warehouse next to all the other dangerous artifacts man was not meant to tamper with, before it kills us all.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: If I should stoop to suggesting that the film is indeed a cat-astrophe, you can be assured that that's a better cat pun than any of those actually in the darn thing (and there are a bunch).
reviews.author: Keva York

reviews.text: Artistically, it's a hairball. There's no story to speak of, Mr. Webber's music is immediately forgettable and, like a cat standing at an open door, it takes forever to get where it's going.
reviews.author: John Anderson

reviews.text: Some things shouldn't be tampered with. I enjoyed Cats onstage, where the theatrical experience worked its magic to great effect. The new film never swept me up as I hoped it might; for all its rich ingredients it felt like a soufflé that wouldn't rise
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: Cats takes an award winning musical and dilutes it in exchange for forgettable star studded performances.
reviews.author: Sharronda Williams

reviews.text: Dazzlingly weird, but occasionally creepy...a phantasmagorical mongrel that fascinates even when it appalls.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: I can't say for sure that all productions of Cats are bad (although I have a hunch) but I can certainly say that this one is.
reviews.author: Max Weiss

reviews.text: This musical misfire sets a new low bar for adapting a Broadway hit.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: What did cats ever do to the tech guys?
reviews.author: Anne Brodie

reviews.text: Lowlighted by Jennifer Hudson's dismal performance of 'Memory,' there is a magnificent ballet halfway through. That's the only good thing I can say about this film.
reviews.author: Tony Medley

reviews.text: Cats is a jellicle disaster (I'm using that term about as well as the movie does). The actors appear to enjoy embarrassing themselves, but that's the only enjoyment derived from this musical hellscape.
reviews.author: Kristen Lopez

reviews.text: Showgirls with fur.
reviews.author: Wade Major

reviews.text: The Cats movie did nothing for me except leave me with insane questions. Save yourself and your kids from jellicle nightmares, and skip this one. Meowy Christmas.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: You will likely hate Cats, but you won't regret watching it. It's a bad studio movie for the ages - and when soulless Disney franchises and remakes are dominating the box office, we should embrace an unprecedented disaster like this while we can.
reviews.author: Alistair Ryder

reviews.text: Cats. They're cats. They're furry and dance well. Cats. They're cats! Welcome to Cats hell.
reviews.author: Jon Negroni

reviews.text: If you have no prior familiarity with the wordy, purring absurdism of "Cats," it'll just hit harder, and you'll likely have a lot of questions.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: I felt as though I was unable to wake up, slowly sinking deeper and deeper into madness. Once it's over, like a dream (or nightmare) you will struggle to recall a detail, but that sinking feeling will leave you nauseous.
reviews.author: Ferdosa Abdi

reviews.text: The biggest weakness of the movie is that the characters look laughable. At worst, they resemble unsightly, horrifying cat/human hybrids.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Francesca, sweetie, I'm so sorry.
reviews.author: Sara Clements

reviews.text: Cats is a testament to not everything should be translated to film.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: [Tom] Hooper is a capable, creative director, but you'd never know it from the furball he's just coughed up on the screen.
reviews.author: Dan Lybarger

reviews.text: Cats is not good. But the blame goes to the clumsy style of director Tom Hooper, not people wearing digital fur.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: I so wanted to slam this movie, but then...
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: It is at times extremely entertaining, with some great performances, but it's also baffling, and the effects would appear to belie the price tag, in that it frequently looks just a bit too cheap.
reviews.author: Shelagh Rowan-Legg

reviews.text: I'll skip the obvious first question, which is just an incredulous "Why??" because I know the answer. It's the pervasive idea that anything popular that isn't a movie has to be turned into one.
reviews.author: Rain Jokinen

reviews.text: Falling short of the expected cat-astrophe, it's more flabbergasting than truly terrible.
reviews.author: Emma Simmonds

reviews.text: Like the Ark of the Covenant, you won't be able to look away as it melts your face off.
reviews.author: Matt Rodriguez

reviews.text: Hooper's utterly bonkers choices make Cats feel like a movie-not from another nation-but from another planet.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Yup, it's a dog alright.
reviews.author: Thom Ernst

reviews.text: I suspect it's the unfathomable quality that has drawn people toCatsfor so long. In that, at least, I will give Tom Hooper credit. He's definitely captured that.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: The truth is, "Cats" is destined for cult status, misunderstood by the uninitiated, unaccepted by the "it's-cool-to-hate" crowd, and cherished by a special brand of audience who sees the value in art that dares to be different.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: It would be more entertaining to see frolicking You Tube kittens than this film of a musical that played better on the stage. You never believe the actors in their roles. It's stilted, pretend acting, diverting your attention to inconsequential things.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: Cats is terrible, but it's also kind of great.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: The whole thing is so badly misbegotten that it keeps its most entertaining elements out of sight.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: It's hard to know how to react to Cats, other than gape in slack-jawed amazement that the dare has continued for so long.
reviews.author: Scott Tobias

reviews.text: There isn't much more to Cats than the experience of sitting back and watching weird-looking performers pretending to be cats while gyrating to Andrew Lloyd Webber songs.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: I am going to recommend Cats on Rotten Tomatoes because if you like Cats: The Show you are going to like or love Cats The Motion Picture.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: It's deliberate doggerel. It's nonsense rhymes. And, for a movie audience accustomed to traits and arcs upon which they can hang their interest, it's deeply boring.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: I'm still slack-jawed and trying to process what I witnessed. (Full Content Review for Parents also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: It's a confusing mess, but one that holds a strange fascination.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: What could've been beautiful imagery in an avant-garde cinema setting is a kitty-litter show of inexplicable choices, one that takes all the fun out of the industry punching bags that are [Rebel] Wilson and James Corden.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: Look, this is a pretty damn faithful rendition of a famously bonkers and unapologetically ridiculous stage show. It's not quite "good," but it's certainly going for it.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: For the life of me, I cannot determine, calculate, or even divine what this movie is, what purpose it serves, and what line of thinking brought it to life.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Three good things to be said about Andrew Lloyd Webber's Broadway musical Cats: It's an impressive showcase for dancers, the costumes are inventive, and the songs, while nonsense, are catchy. Tom Hooper's film adaptation neuters all three aspects.
reviews.author: Karen Han

reviews.text: 'Cats' is one of those expensive $ 100 million products that become cult pieces for the least expected reasons. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: [Cats] doesn't really work. And, more often than not, it's a grotesque burlesque. But it does have a few warm, furry moments.
reviews.author: Stephen Garrett

reviews.text: It's taken the musical Cats nearly 40 years to make its way from the stage to the big screen. Now we know why.
reviews.author: Robert W. Butler

reviews.text: This all-star, all-awful screen take on the smash Broadway musical easily scores as the worst movie of the year and arguably the decade. Cats shouldn't happen to a dog.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: The parts of Cats that work work really well, while many others don't. It's still kinda magical in a goofy sort of way.
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: Does all this work? Well, it depends on how you feel about ... "Cats." Did you love the show? You'll find stuff to love here. Did you hate it? Ditto! Or maybe ... you'll have both reactions? That's possible too.
reviews.author: Jocelyn Noveck

reviews.text: "Cats" turns the most vacuous stage musical of the 1980s into a big-screen litter box for the hammiest of stars to unload into.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: The big screen version of Cats may not be purrfect, but it's lovely, wildly entertaining and sparkles with movie magic.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: I enjoyed the film for what it is. It's London's Got Talent for the feline set.
reviews.author: Sheila O'Malley

reviews.text: I would rather eat glass than watch Cats again, but if someone were to put out a warts-and-all behind-the-scenes documentary on its making, I would watch the hell out of it.
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: Are all the cast being held hostage?
reviews.author: Jamie East

reviews.text: The look of the actors is so strange you can't get over it: It's the Uncanny Alley. The actors have tails and fur, but also hands. The lady cats have bosoms. Millions in digital effects have yielded the strangest species mashup since Manimal.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: Cat-astrophic special effects ruin Tom Hooper's adaptation of the infamous stage musical Cats.
reviews.author: Matthew Dougherty

reviews.text: Well, some aspects of the film are genuinely good, but they're counteracted by so much stupid, creepy and pretentious awfulness that it all comes together into a fascinating train wreck.
reviews.author: Reuben Baron

reviews.text: Years from now, there will be late-night screenings of Cats, with pleasantly drunk moviegoers bellowing for milk alongside Jason Derulo's Rum Tum Tugger and imitating Hudson's melodramatic stylings.
reviews.author: Abby Olcese

reviews.text: 40% of this movie is quite good - the other 60%...not so much...
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: Cats is the kind of bad movie you'll tell your kids about, and they probably won't believe you.
reviews.author: Oscar Goff

reviews.text: It is literally the stuff of nightmares.
reviews.author: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh

reviews.text: Structurally, thematically, rhythmically, the show is built around 'Memory.' If that song brings the house down, nothing else matters. If it doesn't...
reviews.author: Kenneth R. Morefield

reviews.text: I realize "It's not that bad!" won't be used in the Cats advertising campaign, but it is worth noting that the peculiar musical does indeed have merit.
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: This ain't no cat's meow, my Jellicles.
reviews.author: Beth Sullivan

reviews.text: Cats may not be the worst film of 2019, but it's going to earn a spot on many 10 worst lists, and deservedly so.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: You do get used to the feline antics after a while, and if that were the biggest problem, "Cats" might still work at a certain level. The bigger issue is that the film completely lacks tension or any real semblance of plot or story.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: I'm not saying this is "meow-sterpiece" but I do think some of the critics are lying to themselves. In no way is this a good movie but it's an utterly fascinating acid trip of a film
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: CATS, as a film, remains as aggressively formless as the musical. It is, essentially, in film terms, all second act.
reviews.author: Tim Stevens

reviews.text: brace yourself
reviews.author: Chris Hunneysett

reviews.text: Cats brings Webber's Broadway sensation to life as an audaciously bizarre spectacle sure to delight and divide as much as the original musical does.
reviews.author: Sandy Schaefer

reviews.text: This part-people, part-pussycat, faux-feline Hollywood hairball is a me-ouch.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: This movie is a nightmare you let live out its nine lives alone.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: A lot of talented people have done their utmost to make Hooper's vision succeed. Sadly, it doesn't.
reviews.author: Neil Smith

reviews.text: What [director Tom] Hooper's team devised, however, while not totally perfect, does wonderfully translate what stage actors envision for themselves when taking on the roles.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: There are so many surreal creative decisions in Cats that one finds themselves constantly faced with the question "what the hell am I even watching?"
reviews.author: Deirdre Molumby

reviews.text: Meow. Well, I suppose the appropriate term here is woof. "Cats," the adaptation of the smash Broadway musical, is a real dog.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: What we have here is future technology that, to borrow an old Irish phrase, needs to be put beyond use. Shoo.
reviews.author: Tara Brady

reviews.text: Cats is a special kind of terrible. No matter how ridiculous it gets, the cast never once backs down. It's a trainwreck from start to finish, but the sort of trainwreck that captures your attention with its audacity and never lets you go.
reviews.author: Charlie Ridgely

reviews.text: A surreal circus of man-animals whose insane musical ramblings frequently cross the line into the realm of madness, but somehow still manages to ensnare us, against all odds and our own best efforts.
reviews.author: Tyler Smith

reviews.text: It's every bit as baffling, weird and horrifying as you expected. It's certainly something that you've never seen before - but there's probably a very good reason for that.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

reviews.text: Ill-concieved and ill-executed, this incarnation of Cats leans in on the effects to the expense of most of the performances.
reviews.author: Bill Watters

reviews.text: Cats has beautiful production design, a few great performances by James Corden. Taylor Swift and Ian McClellan and spectacular choreography by Andy Blankenbueller. But it left me just as confused as the Broadway show did regardless of its hit status.
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: A total misfire. Nauseating, anemic and cringe-inducing. The only way to experience it while clean and sober without any suffering is to wear eye shades and ear plugs.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Cats is a head on collision between movie musicals and incompetent technology in which there are no survivors, only miles of morbid curiosity and rubbernecking.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Perhaps I missed what all the purring is about, but the spectacle is more farcical than anything else
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: By the time I left the theater, I wasn't even sure what a real cat looked like anymore.
reviews.author: Clint Worthington

reviews.text: Congratulations to dogs.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: Cats is the kind of modern movie musical that will have you humming the visual effects as you leave the cinema...For such a feather-weight musical the direction is just too dour. It's like trying to have a skip in your step while wearing moon boots.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: If you can overlook the problematic CGI and enjoy the craft of the performances, Cats may be a unique blend of musical and movie. But that pure spectacle boils down to a skin and bone plot, enclosed in a strange dystopia that lacks genuine heart.
reviews.author: Jennifer Bisset

reviews.text: Doubtless lovers of Andrew Lloyd Webber will flock to see it, but it's as messy as a cat's litter tray.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: The problem lies with the source material, which will make audiences want to claw out their own eyes just for a change of pace.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: The weirdest thing about this very weird film is how dull it feels; how devoid of spirit.
reviews.author: Luke Buckmaster

reviews.text: Sensational performances from Jennifer Hudson to Taylor Swift to Ian McKellen to Judi Dench help make this entertaining adaptation hit all the right notes.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: I felt the light inside me slowly fading.
reviews.author: Hannah Strong

reviews.text: Finally, a whole new generation can discover that the Cats musical is two hours of human-feline hybrids without genitals having no-touch sex and begging for death via song.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: I never thought I would say "There's something for everyone." But really there is in this film.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: The ultimate effect of the neon and glitter-drenched CGI extravaganza is Hellraiser 2 by way of Roald Dahl, a family entertainment spectacularly drunk on its own supply of batshit.
reviews.author: Chris Feil

reviews.text: Will live on in every viewer's memory, now and forever. Its weirdness is unforgettable.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: This version is fun enough for a musical theater junkie. The songs are well done and the dancing is impressive. All the actors are trying their hardest and the visual style is unique.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: It's a fun watch, even if it's not... Purrfect.
reviews.author: Chuck Yarborough

reviews.text: The weak source material paired with Tom Hooper's incompetent direction is truly a wonder to behold.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: There is a thin line between idiocy and genius, and Cats pukes a hairball on it and rubs its ass all over it.
reviews.author: Hoai-Tran Bui

reviews.text: CATS is not a version I'd recommend being anyone's first experience in witnessing the renowned musical. And that's saying something.
reviews.author: Sarah Musnicky

reviews.text: The plot is slight, but if you just look at it as Step Up Felines then it's fine holiday entertainment.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: Once Tom Hooper's 110 minutes of Cats are over, theater is dead. One lucky Jellicle cat is dead. And we unchosen ones are left, tragically, to continue living.
reviews.author: Lena Wilson

reviews.text: Cats is for the dogs, but then again, even most dogs know to avoid the stinky stuff.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: You'll find that in the end, you're still a dog person.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: There is something magical about the simple fact that this movie exists, in all its obscene, absurd wonder, its terrible filmmaking choices and bursts of jaw-dropping talent.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: I found "Cats" pretty bland, but it has its moments of catnip, and as a holiday movie option that anyone could see, it might be just the ticket.
reviews.author: G. Allen Johnson

reviews.text: By the final scene, by which my eyebrows were hurting from being raised so high (the winning cat goes to the Heavyside Layer in a chandelier? What is this, "Phantom of the Opera"?), I was just tired. As was "Cats." Meow.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: A musical of course necessitates the suspension of disbelief, but Mr. Hooper seems never to have quite made up his mind on whether to approach the material with theatrics or realism and winds up with something the cat dragged in.
reviews.author: Martin Tsai

reviews.text: Cats may flop but it will be found by a likeminded audience, maybe the same one that rescued The Greatest Showman. Don't be the sourpuss to tell these people they're wrong.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: The intended humour mostly falls flat (lame jokes like "cat got your tongue" are neither funny nor logical), but there's something in the garish, glorious failure of it that can absolutely be enjoyed. It is unbelievable that it even exists.
reviews.author: John Nugent

reviews.text: Oh God, my eyes.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: You won't be able to look away, but you might wish you could forget the "memory" of Cats by the movie's end.
reviews.author: Corey Chichizola

reviews.text: I gasped with laughter, I covered my face, I pulled at my hair, I clasped my hands over my mouth to keep from screaming. Cats had broken me, and I'd never felt happier.
reviews.author: Angie Han

reviews.text: Cats isn't the cat-astrophe that everyone either feared or hoped for back in July, but it isn't a triumphant vindication of Hooper's vision, either.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber

reviews.text: It gives me very little satisfaction to tell you that Cats takes the prize for being one of the most excruciatingly boring films of 2019.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: First off, full disclosure -- I am not a cat person. Second off -- after watching this frankly mortifying film adaptation of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cats, I'm not altogether sure I am a movie person anymore either.
reviews.author: Alan Corr

reviews.text: One of the weirdest and most garish monstrosities to be birthed out of the Hollywood studio system in this century.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: It all just feels so wrong.
reviews.author: David Sexton

reviews.text: Its wild, wacky spirit and crazy creative choices make it an equal parts awful and audacious spectacle to behold.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: All I can say is that Mr. Mistoffelees definitely is the best, and maybe this entire movie is overtly sexual for absolutely no reason. So, you know, fun for the entire family.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: I'm a dog man myself. But Hooper has made a surprisingly good fist of bringing it to life.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Cats succeeds on its own terms. Its own harebrained, roller coaster, what did we do last night that has me waking up in a temple in Kyoto wearing someone else's pants way.
reviews.author: Robert Daniels

reviews.text: A bunch of well-known celebrities get turned into singing, scenery-chewing digital kitties in the utterly absurd yet oddly charming movie musical version of the Broadway hit.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: Even after 110 tumbling, tail-swishing, deeply psychedelic minutes, it's hard to know if you ever really knew anything - except that C is for Cats, C is for Crazy, and C is probably the grade this cinematic lunacy deserves.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: Finding any high point in Cats, though, takes some serious scratching.
reviews.author: Tim Robey

reviews.text: What I didn't know is what a formless blob it is, a jumble of musical numbers devoid of plot and pacing, and director Tom Hooper... can do nothing to change that.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: Without the presence of hard-working troupers in fun fur in this "Cats," all that's left are canned images of fit-looking people meowing and raising their rumps high in the air.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: On a scale of one to Zemeckis, Hooper's Cats boldly goes beyond the uncanny valley and creates a tier of its own.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: Hooper is not my man for film musicals.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: You must witness the hubris of director Tom Hooper. You must witness the hubris of Hollywood. The hubris of these performers.
reviews.author: Alex Cranz

reviews.text: This visually dense adaptation of the Andrew Lloyd Webber hit is at once too crazy for this world, and not quite crazy enough.
reviews.author: Eric Kohn

reviews.text: If the goal was to provide a holiday musical event that's fun for the whole family, it's a good idea in theory, packaged in the wrong litter box.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: I didn't hate it.
reviews.author: Kerry Lengel

reviews.text: Sadly, this uneven eyesore turns out to be every bit the Jellicle catastrophe the haters anticipated, a half-digested hairball of a movie...
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: Director Tom Hooper's movie is a huge failure because he's completely abandoned the fundamentals of what made "Cats" a terrific show.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: A spectacular disaster...This movie feels like a prank but I don't know on whom.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: With its grotesque design choices and busy, metronomic editing, "Cats" is as uneasy on the eyes as a Hollywood spectacle can be, tumbling into an uncanny valley between mangy realism and dystopian artifice.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: The most inexplicably bizarre film of the year, it's jawdropping for all the wrong reasons.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: What happens in musical theater should stay in musical theater.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: As an adaptation, Cats is declawed, never delving fully into the possibilities offered by its proportion-manipulating trick photography and its animated cast. As a big-budget spectacle, it's a triumphant disaster, if one at least born from a unique idea.
reviews.author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer

reviews.text: I found it all exhausting.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: It's literally incredible. I hope I never see it again.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: Of the thought, of the thought, of what on earth to do now. "Pretend to be cats!" says a director. They reply ... "Me? How?"
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Tom Hooper's jarring fever dream of a spectacle is like something that escaped from Dr. Moreau's creature laboratory, an un-catty valley hybrid of physical and digital that unsettles and crashes way more often than it enchants.
reviews.author: Robert Abele

reviews.text: As far as motion picture musicals are concerned, Cats is...a cinematic disgrace.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: Shoddy visual effects can be forgiven, but the biggest issue is that there isn't much energy to many of the performances, probably because even the actors were deeply puzzled as to what they were doing
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Cats is the worst thing to happen to cats since dogs.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: The Cats movie is about cats, yes. But it also should have been about, well, Cats.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: Cats is a strange beast to begin with, but the combination of strange CGI makes the translation from stage to screen even worse.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: Cats out of the bag, let's put them back in. At best, Cats is an interesting exercise in the boundaries of filmmaking. At the worst, which it treads closer to, it's a disturbing, confusing, and misguided acid trip of a musical.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: This adaptation gets straight to the heart of the material, which is basically two hours of stray cats introducing themselves.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

reviews.text: Fans of the stage musical may swoon, but others will be severely allergic.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: Big-screen musical adaptation is both strange and magical.
reviews.author: Lynnette Nicholas

synopsis: A tribe of cats must decide yearly which one will ascend to the Heaviside Layer and come back to a new life.
